_exec_summary.SummaryText:
h Administration (OSHA) regulates worker and chemical safety, with provisions of Worker Right-to-know.  The Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-know Act has 2 annual reports requiring the tracking of chemicals stored, used and released at the facility.  Waste waters are analyzed before releasing to a surface stream and under a state permit, and discharging to a publicly owned treatment works under a city permit (by agreements with the EPA to enforce the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination Act).  Surface storm water runoff content is monitored to comply with the Clean Water Act regulations, and ABE South Dakota, LLC maintains a Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plan.  The facility maintains and complies with a Title V air permit under the Clean Air Act Amendments (administered by the State of South Dakota).  In addition to regulations for similar production facilities, the production of ethanol is under the purview of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, which requires the facility to maintain a license and surety bond, and regulations overseen by the Department of Transportation.

The fuel ethanol facility in Huron has experienced one spill in the past five years.  No major injuries were reported.  On 05/17/2008 the plant had an equipment failure at our rail load out station, and we spilled 5000 gallons of denatured ethanol.   

ABE South Dakota, LLC employees are not trained as Incident Commanders under the standards of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA).  All emergencies arising on the property owned by and under the control of ABE South Dakota, LLC will be coordinated by a company defined emergency coordinator or successor until such time as a trained Incident Commander assumes command of the emergency.

In an emergency situation, employees will be evacuated to designated assembly areas, where a head count will be taken to account for all employees on duty.  The emergency coordinator will also ensure that all necessar

ABE South Dakota, LLC is a fuel ethanol plant operating in Huron, SD.  This facility is able to process approximately 11.4 million bushels of grain per year and produce up to 30 million gallons of denatured ethanol per year. The facility produces dried distillers grains with solids (DDGS) and wet distiller's grains with solids (WDGS) as by-products.  

Grain is received by truck and dumped into an enclosed receiving pit or delivered by conveyor. The grain is transported from the receiving pit to grain storage bins. The grain is then transported from the grain storage bins to a hammer mill. The hammer mill grinds the grain into flour which is blended with hot water and enzymes to produce a mash.  The mash is pumped to the fermentation process. In the fermentation process, yeast and enzymes are added to the mash to convert the starch to sugars, which are then converted to ethanol and carbon dioxide. The resulting liquid (beer) contains ethanol. After approximately 50 hours, the beer in the fermentation tank(s) is pumped to a beer well.    

In the distillation process, the beer from the beer well is pumped to the top of the beer column (stripper) and is heated by vapors from the Evaporators. The ethanol vaporizes and is collected in the rectifier, producing approximately 187-190 proof ethanol (93% ethanol and 7% water). Where it then is pumped to either the 190 holding take or to the 190 reflux tank, where it may be pumped back to the rectifier to help proof up the alcohol vapors. The 190 proof ethanol is superheated and sent to one of three molecular sieve beds where the remaining water is removed to produce 200 proof ethanol (100% ethanol). The 200 proof ethanol is condensed and pumped to outside storage tanks.

These outside storage tanks contain up to 200,000 gallons of denatured ethanol and are exempt from the CAA 112(r)(7)'s Risk Management Program.  The contents of these tanks does not meet the NFPA -4 criteria. Information found on the MSDS indicates t

y notifications to Fire Departments, Police, Highway Patrol, etc. have been made.  

The operations personnel will ensure that all appropriate processes are shut down and deenergized, if this action will not risk bodily harm or further damages to the environment, property or equipment.  No employee will be directed to perform duties beyond that of their training.

ABE South Dakota, LLC is continually updating operating practices and procedures, which includes operations personnel training.  Plant efficiencies are being improved, and with that additional control equipment is being evaluated to improve safety and environmental protection.  The increased awareness and training is also improving the plant safety.

hat Denatured Ethanol has an NFPA flammability rating of 3 (NFPA-3).  ABE South Dakota, LLC follows the general duty provisions to operate the Denatured Ethanol safely under the CAA 112(r)(1) (the General Duty Clause).

The 200 proof ethanol is denatured with gasoline. Denaturing is required to render the ethanol unfit for human consumption. The gasoline used may either be unleaded gasoline or natural gasoline (sometimes referred to as well head gasoline or well head drip gas). The facility has chosen natural gasoline, due to restrictions on specifications of impurities for fuel ethanol in some states. 


The whole stillage (beer without the ethanol) is processed through centrifuges to produce thin stillage and a solid fraction. The thin stillage is sent to an evaporator where the water is evaporated to produce a syrup containing about 27 to 30 percent solids. The syrup is added with the solid fraction, which is referred to as wet distiller's grain and solids (WDGS). This WDGS contains approximately 65 percent moisture and is sold as animal feed or refined through an additional process to produce dried distillers grains with solids (DDGS). When producing DDGS, the WDGS is sent processed through a dryer producing a 12 percent moisture product. This 12 percent moisture product is referred to as DDGS and is also sold as animal feed. 

For ABE South Dakota, LLC, this RMP is completed for the anhydrous ammonia nurse tanks and the denaturant storage tank along with associated piping, pumps and metering controls. 

ABE South Dakota, LLC has an active preventive maintenance program that incorporates the inspection of the natural gasoline (denaturant) storage tank and the associated piping and equipment.  In an effort to assure protection of the environment, the denaturant tank is situated in a bermed area to provide secondary containment for the denaturant tank contents in the event of an accidental uncontrolled release.  ABE South Dakota, LLC uses the local fire d

epartment to respond to emergencies, but also has an emergency action plan.  In the event of a large release of denaturant, the Plan calls for contacting two local construction company's with the equipment to build additional dikes and containment, as necessary.

In addition to the physical protection of secondary containment, there is also a fusible link valve on the denaturant tank.  This valve closes in the event of a fire, preventing the tank to drain through a damaged header or ruptured pipe.  The facility also maintains a portable trailer with a fire-fighting foam eductor capable of connecting to a fire hydrant to foam flammable liquid fires.  This trailer has been made available for local fire department use in the event of a community emergency.
 
ABE South Dakota, LLC also has a Process Safety Management (PSM) program.  We believe this is another tool to enhance employee safety programs, protect the environment and continue safe operation of equipment.  As a rule, very few hazardous chemicals are stored on site in a quantity to cause significant problems in a release situation.  ABE South Dakota, LLC actively trains employees on chemical use, hazard communication and handling procedures. In addition, as part of this program, ABE South Dakota went through an extensive pre-startup safety review. (PSSR)    

Only one substance is present at this facility in sufficient quantities to be regulated under the Risk Management Planning regulations.  A single tank of natural gasoline, sometimes called drip gas, stores a maximum capacity of 30,000 gallons.  This tank measures 10 feet in diameter and is 30 feet tall.  This tank contents are used to denature ethanol to render it unfit for human consumption.  

ABE South Dakota, LLC is subject to and complies with several federal and state regulations.  These regulations govern the storage and use of hazardous chemicals, purity of waste waters, air emissions and product tracking.  The Occupational Safety and Healt
